DOC.HEAD: Round-Table Talks Next Week; General Strike Called Thursday
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Politburo on Tuesday proposed round-table talks on the country's future with other official and newly active opposition groups. The action came after an independent trade union, Podkrepa, proposed warning strikes for Wednesday, presumably in selected places, and a general strike Thursday to push demands for the talks. It was not clear whether the Politburo offer was in response to Podkrepa's threat of the first general strike in Bulgaria since the Communist takeover after World War II. It also was not clear whether the strikes would go ahead as planned. Podkrepa is one of several opposition groups that have been allowed to function publicly since Todor Zhivkov was ousted as Communist leader Nov. 10. An initial meeting took place Dec. 15 between the ruling Communists and representatives of opposition groups. Zhivkov's ouster came amid a wave of change that swept the East bloc, beginning with Poland and Hungary and spreading to East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Romania. Petar Mladenov, who took over from Zhivkov, has pledged to scrap the Communist Party's monopoly on power, remove its guaranteed leading role from the Constitution and hold free elections by May. Also Tuesday, reform Communists demanded the resignation of the entire existing party Central Committee, elected under Zhivkov, and announced plans to split from the party and form a faction known as the Alternative Socialist Association. The group will hold a meeting Jan. 12, the state news agency BTA reported. The group also wants the party to share with emerging alternative parties the extensive property amassed over the last four decades, its funds and printing presses, BTA said.
